string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: disclaimer this resource was created by the university of manchester librarys copyright guidance service and adapted by manchester metropolitan university library under a cc-by-nc licence. the information provided within this resource is intended as general guidance only, and an interpretation of current copyright issues and practice at the manchester metropolitan university. whilst every effort is made to ensure that this resource is up-to-date and accurate, mmu does not warrant, nor does it accept any responsibility or liability for, the accuracy or completeness of the content or for any loss which may arise from reliance on information contained in it. it is not a definite guide and should not be construed as legal advice. this resource is available for reuse under a cc-by-nc licence. for full licence terms, visit the creative commons website. contact manmet librarys copyright team for more information - email library@mmu.ac.uk. close [x] can i use it? this interactive resource will help you to work out whether you can use specific types of learning material in your teaching, and how you can use them without breaching copyright. there are many grey areas in copyright law, and the answers we provide here may not always be definitive. if you are in any doubt, please contact us for advice by emailing library@mmu.ac.uk. view disclaimer. start start start start start start

no no no no no no is it in the public domain? yes yes yes yes yes yes public domain works are those whose intellectual property rights have expired, been forfeited, or are otherwise inapplicable. for example, creative work where the author died more than 70 years ago. when trying to determine whether something is in the public domain or not, consider the following: the rules of your own country apply (ie. uk copyright law) a reproduction of a work has a new copyright life (eg. a digital image of an old photograph) any adaptation of a work is a new copyright work. copyright work. free to use! public domain works are no longer subject to copyright restrictions, so you are free to use the material however you like. x public domain works are those whose intellectual property rights have expired, been forfeited, or are otherwise inapplicable. for example, creative work where the author died more than 70 years ago. when trying to determine whether something is in the public domain or not, consider the following: the rules of your own country apply (ie. uk copyright law) a reproduction of a work has a new copyright life (eg. a digital image of an old photograph) any adaptation of a work is a new copyright work.

no no no no no no is it open access or creative commons licensed? yes yes yes yes yes yes there are a number of different creative commons (cc) licences, which allow various levels of permission. the basic, most open licence is cc-0 which allows anyone to reuse and adapt materials for any purpose, with no need to attribute the original author. a number of letter designations can be added to impose further restrictions, such as nc (non-commercial) and nd (no derivatives). these can be combined to meet specific requirements. you are free to use cc licensed material as long as you adhere to the terms of the type of licence that the material has been released under. you can use the creative commons search page to find cc licensed content. free to use! creative commons materials have been specifically licensed to enable people to reuse them. you are free to use these materials, as long as you adhere to the terms of the licence that the material has been released under. x there are a number of different creative commons (cc) licences, which allow various levels of permission. the basic, most open licence is cc-0 which allows anyone to reuse and adapt materials for any purpose, with no need to attribute the original author. a number of letter designations can be added to impose further restrictions, such as nc (non-commercial) and nd (no derivatives). these can be combined to meet specific requirements. you are free to use cc licensed material as long as you adhere to the terms of the type of licence that the material has been released under. you can use the creative commons search page to find cc licensed content.

you cant use this. entire books are not covered by any licences or copyright exceptions. this means they cant be digitised, copied or shared unless they are in the public domain (out of copyright). x photocopy / scan of an entire printed book photocopy / scan of an entire printed book photocopy / scan of an entire printed book photocopy / scan of an entire printed book photocopy / scan of an entire printed book photocopy / scan of an entire printed book photocopy / scan of a chapter of a book photocopy / scan of a chapter of a book photocopy / scan of a chapter of a book photocopy / scan of a chapter of a book photocopy / scan of a chapter of a book photocopy / scan of a chapter of a book what do you want to copy?

you cant use this. this isnt permitted under any copyright exceptions, and it would be high risk. you need to obtain the permission of the rights holder. x x x x fair dealing in certain circumstances, some works may be copied under a copyright exception where its considered to be fair dealing. fair dealing is not defined in law, and the fairness of a particular use will be judged according to its own circumstances. however, there are a few factors to consider when assessing the fairness, including: the amount copied avoid copying excessive amounts of a work, and be aware that in some cases the type of work may be a factor. the purpose of copying if the purpose is for teaching a limited number of students, this may be considered fair. the damage that copying may do to the market for, or sales of, the work where the economic impact is not significant, the use may count as fair dealing. close [x] close [x] close [x] close [x] free to use! you can use this under the terms of our cla licence or a fair dealing copyright exception. contact the digitisation team x x x x cla licence our copyright licensing agency (cla) licence covers the photocopying and scanning of most uk publications and some us and international publishers. it allows: multiple photocopies of limited extracts from copyright protected printed books, journals and magazines digital copies of limited extracts from copyright protected printed books, journals and magazines details of excluded uk and us publishers, and included overseas countries, can be found on the clas website. close [x] close [x] close [x] close [x] free to use! under the research and private study exception, researchers and students are allowed to copy limited extracts of works for non-commercial research and private study. this includes text, images, sound and video recordings. the amount is limited by fair dealing and must be sufficiently acknowledged/attributed. x x x x free to use! era (educational recording agency) licence the era provides licensing schemes to member he institutions to cover the use of recorded broadcast media in teaching and learning. the era licence grants the right to copy, access and use, for non-commercial educational purposes, broadcast output of eras members in the form of era recordings. mmu currently has an era licence. this also allows licensed era recordings to be accessed by students and teachers online from outside the premises of their establishment. close [x] close [x] close [x] close [x] you cant use this this isnt permitted under any research and private study researchers and students are allowed to copy limited extracts of works for non-commercial research and private study. this includes text, images, sound and video recordings. the amount is limited by fair dealing and must be sufficiently acknowledged/attributed. fair dealing in certain circumstances, some works may be copied under a copyright exception where its considered to be fair dealing. fair dealing is not defined in law, and the fairness of a particular use will be judged according to its own circumstances. however, there are a few factors to consider when assessing the fairness, including: the amount copied avoid copying excessive amounts of a work, and be aware that in some cases the type of work may be a factor. the purpose of copying if the purpose is for teaching a limited number of students, this may be considered fair. the damage that copying may do to the market for, or sales of, the work where the economic impact is not significant, the use may count as fair dealing. era (educational recording agency) licence the era provides licensing schemes to member he institutions to cover the use of recorded broadcast media in teaching and learning. the era licence grants the right to copy, access and use, for non-commercial educational purposes, broadcast output of eras members in the form of era recordings. mmu currently has an era licence. this also allows licensed era recordings to be accessed by students and teachers online from outside the premises of their establishment. creative commons creative commons is a non-profit organisation that provides licensing information aimed at achieving a mutual sharing and flexible approach to copyright. their easy-to-use copyright licences provide a simple, standardised way to give the public permission to share and use creative work. you are free to use cc licensed material as long as you adhere to the terms of the type of licence that the material has been released under. you can use the creative commons search page to find cc licensed content. cla licence our copyright licensing agency (cla) licence covers the photocopying and scanning of most uk publications and some us and international publishers. it allows: multiple photocopies of limited extracts from copyright protected printed books, journals and magazines digital copies of limited extracts from copyright protected printed books, journals and magazines details of excluded uk and us publishers, and included overseas countries, can be found on the clas website. public domain public domain works are those whose intellectual property rights have expired, been forfeited, or are otherwise inapplicable. for example, creative work where the author died more than 70 years ago. when trying to determine whether something is in the public domain or not, consider the following: the rules of your own country apply (ie. uk copyright law) a reproduction of a work has a new copyright life (eg. a digital image of an old photograph) any adaptation of a work is a new copyright work. cla licence creative commons (cc) era licence fair dealing public domain research and private study glossary of copyright terms close glossary
